skill.name: simpy
skill.description: Process-based discrete-event simulation framework in Python. Use this skill when building simulations of systems with processes, queues, resources, and time-based events such as manufacturing systems, service operations, network traffic, logistics, or any system where entities interact with shared resources over time.

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged 253 potential issues, but evaluation shows these are false positives. The 'external_commands' findings are from markdown code examples using backticks for documentation, not actual shell execution. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' findings refer to legitimate use of random.seed() for simulation reproducibility. No actual security risks identified.

content.value_statement: SimPy enables you to model complex systems with processes, queues, and shared resources. Simulate manufacturing lines, service operations, network traffic, and logistics to optimize performance before implementation.
actual_capabilities: Create process-based simulations with Python generators
Model resource contention and queueing behavior
Monitor utilization, wait times, and throughput
Export results to CSV for analysis
Simulate real-time systems with wall-clock synchronization
limitations: Not suitable for continuous simulations with fixed time steps
Requires Python generator functions for process definition
Simulation speed depends on model complexity

use_cases.title: Optimize Manufacturing Lines
use_cases.description: Model production workflows to identify bottlenecks, balance capacity, and minimize cycle times before physical implementation.

use_cases.title: Simulate Network Traffic
use_cases.description: Analyze packet routing, bandwidth allocation, and latency under various load conditions to optimize network performance.

use_cases.title: Design Queue Systems
use_cases.description: Simulate customer flow in banks, hospitals, or retail to determine optimal staffing levels and reduce wait times.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Queue Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a SimPy simulation of customers arriving at a bank with 2 tellers. Customers arrive every 3-5 minutes and service takes 5-8 minutes. Run for 8 hours and show average wait time.

prompt_templates.title: Manufacturing Line
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a SimPy model of a 3-stage manufacturing line where parts go through cutting (10 min), assembly (15 min), and inspection (5 min). Each stage has 1 machine. Analyze throughput.

prompt_templates.title: Network Packet Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Simulate packets arriving at a router with 100 Mbps bandwidth. Packets are 1-5 KB and arrive at 50 packets/second. Show queue length and packet loss under peak load.

prompt_templates.title: Resource Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Model a cloud data center with 10 servers handling 3 types of jobs (short: 1-5 min, medium: 10-20 min, long: 30-60 min). Jobs arrive randomly. Find optimal server allocation per job type.

best_practices: Always use context managers (with statement) when requesting resources to ensure proper cleanup
Set random.seed() for reproducible results when comparing different scenarios
Monitor and collect data throughout the simulation, not just at the end
Validate your model by testing simple cases with known analytical solutions
anti_patterns: Forgetting yield statements in process functions will cause processes to run instantly
Reusing events that have already been triggered will cause simulation errors
Using blocking Python operations like sleep() instead of env.timeout()
Creating resources without proper capacity limits leads to unrealistic models

faq.question: What's the difference between Environment and RealtimeEnvironment?
faq.answer: Environment runs simulations as fast as possible, while RealtimeEnvironment synchronizes simulation time with wall-clock time for real-time applications.

faq.question: How do I choose the right resource type?
faq.answer: Use Resource for basic capacity limits, PriorityResource for priority queuing, Container for bulk materials, and Store for object storage.

faq.question: Can I interrupt a process in SimPy?
faq.answer: Yes, use process.interrupt() to forcefully resume a process. This is useful for modeling preemption or timeouts.

faq.question: How do I collect custom statistics?
faq.answer: Use the ResourceMonitor class or create custom monitors by patching resource methods and tracking events during simulation.

faq.question: What's the best way to model parallel processes?
faq.answer: Start multiple processes with env.process() and use yield with & operator to wait for all to complete.

faq.question: How can I export simulation results?
faq.answer: Use the export_csv() method in ResourceMonitor or write custom export functions using collected data dictionaries.
